review_title: Great Learning Opportunities, But Not a Healthy Work Environment
pros: There are always great opportunities to learn more about professional development and new products within the company. It's a great place to start your career
cons:
Technology, No Work/Life Balance, Lack of Guidance

1. There are always technology issues that cause a bottleneck with work. It can take hours, if not a week to resolve a system issue that is preventing you from completing your job. This causes unnecessary tension between your manager and team members, because you cannot complete your work on time. 

2. Depending on your team, expect to work at least 10-12 hours with no complaints. My manager and co-worker work 14-16 hours per day, so it was normalized. You are perceived as not working hard enough if you plan on working 40 hours/week.

3. Performing new functions is daunting because many of the procedures are out of date and missing key steps. At times, people are condescending when you ask questions, and expect you to be an expert on new things.

review_title: Decent people, uncompetitive pay, no clear path for advancement for most
pros: Most people are polite and reasonable. Overall respectful culture, reasonable work hours.
cons:
Large gulf between upper management and the rest of the company. Frequent layoffs, increasingly within the legal team.  Ongoing effort to move functions offshore to low cost locations, including legal work. 

Forced ranking of employees on a curve within each group, which has a clear design of setting up future layoffs and creates an environment where peers are not encouraged to help one another. 

Low base pay relative to the market.  There is an increasing push to make bonuses more differentiated based on performance ranking, but this only partially makes up for low base salaries for some employees and is not something to be relied on year to year. 

There is a clear message that there are only a few spots available for top ranking on the curve within each group and no one should count on receiving top rankings repeatedly.  So a good bonus one year does not create any sense of predictable financial reward for performance going forward.

No clear path for advancement for most, although within upper management the same individuals get promoted repeatedly.   These people are generally very smart, highly qualified people, so it's not that their success is undeserved, but the overall impression created is that most credit for good results go to a very few individuals at the top, with the rest of the company seeing few predictable rewards for good performance and constant threat of layoff in the background.

pros: Good benefit 3 weeks vacations, with pension and new technologies to work on daily tasks. Colleagues are fun to work with. cons: Bad company with no possibility to grow unless you are very closed to the managers or VP. It is a little corrupted but that is the way it is. Even you work hard and strive for excellence, you won`t get promoted if you are not the favorable one. It is also very bureacratic and everything has to be decided by the big dudes in Boston. Very low salary. If you work in a telus or fido customer service department, you probably make more than an associate II. Forget Associate I because it`s a full time mcdonald salary. Long hours and it is a ``if you leave early, it means that you don`t work hard enough`` style of working environment. The company is trying to ship tasks to India in order to save cost and if your department is going to be shipped to India, it means that you have no values and anyone in India can replace you with a 50% discount. The only reason why State Street has office in Montreal, Quebec is because the governement gives an incentive for having an office in Quebec. That`s it. Whatever you do can be replaced by an indian guy in India at 50% discount of your current salary. You are a number in their financial statements.

review_title: A lot of organizational shortcomings and ineffective leadership
pros: This place provides some good experience for recent college graduate.
cons: Management promises too much to win new businesses (understandable because the industry is fiercely competitive). However, they do not stress test new models/processes enough before integrating them into production. As a result, there are many long nights due to manual work needed to fix broken processes. Leaders often fail to recognize their failure. Instead, they push employees to shoulder more work to fulfill what they initially promised the clients. Overworked individuals tend to leave quickly, leading to more work divided among remaining individuals. The team culture implies that those who do not stay are not workaholics (as if they are so brainwashed by capitalism that being a workaholic is a positive personality trait). Problematic culture and ineffective organizational strategy.

pros: None, a truly awful place to work
cons:
Company cuts every corner possible. The computers are as so cheap. Useless virtual computers with the computing power of a weak computer 10 years ago. They are not capable to support the datasets business units require to meet the demands of the job. 

60 hour work weeks on the regular. Expect to work weekends, then still get questioned why you could meet deadlines working 7 days a week without seeing the light of day. Meanwhile staffing onshore is reduced to 10% of what it was 4 years ago, only to replace lost employees with untrained contractors off the streets of India with no education and no experience. The new responsibility of onshore employees is to remediate all the deficiencies and shortcomings that come with the cost cutting of hiring these contractors that demonstrate no ability to think critically. Expect to be blamed for issues that are the direct result of hiring untrained people. Management tells you we are responsible for their work, while simultaneously telling you not to review their work. Management sabotages the careers and well-being of associates and 1st/2nd level managers to cover their own butts for bad decisions they made.

Work from home has become live at work, where work bleeds into every waking moment of your life. 5AM-12PM, you're expected to be online and available to work. You get a nice 5 hour break from midnight to 5AM where you are not bothered. If you dont log on till 730AM you're viewed as a late starter and if you log off before 8PM you're viewed as cutting out early.

Compensation is an absolute joke. The teams doing the bulk of the work are paid the least. Bonuses are ever-shrinking, even in years with record profits. During the corporate tax cuts, instead of giving employees raises, they gave us some BS about investing back in our wellbeing through other programs. They claimed to enhance benefits, only to see them cut costs the next year by going to a cheaper, much worse medical plan.

job_title: Senior Associate Emerging Lead in São Paulo, São Paulo
pros: Brand value and less work pressure
cons: The management is biased , the Hyderabad India was started 3 years back with all new recruits ans mostly Indian people. Undeserving people got promotions and became manager who can’t even utter one sentence properly , have no idea on how to behave with resources, how to manage the team, only good at impressing seniors. Performance , hard work has no value and if you ask for what you deserve they will put you on PIP and give promotion to their internally favoured personnel. I worked in onshore for State Street , and worked in Hyderabad as well but the experience is entirely opposite . If you are a woman and have a voice and if your seniors/ managers are all men then just forget about getting the respect and things that you deserve. Patriarchy is there in this Indian management which is not there in all teams but most teams has it. There is not much work also and hence at the end of the year you can’t even demand that you did a lot and deserve. They will purposely put you in such projects where your skill set and creativity will become stagnant. So better avoid joining this organisation in India. If you get an opportunity in other country go for it.

review_title: Good place to work with worst management
pros: I worked with State corporation in technology team and yes state street offers decent salary. And some average benefits. It's a big brand. So the brand name worth a lot.
cons:
1. Worst Management 
2. Too much white people dominated. There is no voice of Indian managers and they love to lick the boots of onshore managers.
3. Too much politics. Oh yes, how could I forget that manager always has a favourite guy and a woman to roam around as his mistress.
4. Force you to work on public holidays and weekends too as on shore managers need to take their long vacations as we Indians dont have families.
4. If we raise our voice against all these the india boot licking managers simply says you guys should be much more flexible. 
5. Forget it if you have family or fiance, because the company will suck your last breath till you give up.

job_title: Client Service Senior Associate in London, England
pros: Employees were friendly, cafe was a nice place to be once away from work and surrounding areas nice in summer.
cons: Managers ignore warning signs of teams and individuals breaking down due to stress, long hours and not being appreciated. Expected to get on with it. True story, there was a mental health seminar being held in the building to support staff, no one including me could attend as our work loads were far too heavy and teams stretched too thin. Management had no comment at the time.
